[[File:Arthur Tolkien 14 February 1896.j: On [[14 February]] [[1896]], a five-year-old [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] wrote '''[[Letters not published in "The Letters of J.R.R. Tolkien"
*'''Description:''' The letter was dictated by Tolkien to his nurse, but was never sent since his mother [[Mabel Suffield
thumb]]: Mabel]] received a telegram on the same day saying that Arthur had [[Wikipedia:Bleeding
column3: haemorrhaged]] (he died on the following day). It is the earliest known  letter composed by Tolkien.<ref name=Life>Judith Priestman, ''[[Tolkien: Life and Legend]]'', p. 11</ref>

[[File:Arthur Tolkien 14 February 1896.j: *'''Publication:''' The letter was quoted in ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]'' (p. 16). A reproduction of the letter appeared in ''[[Tolkien: Life and Legend]]'' (p. 11).

thumb]]: I am so glad I am coming back to see you it is such a long time since we came away from you I hope the ship will bring us all back to you Mamie and [[Hilary Tolkien
column3: Baby]] and me ... I am got such a big man now because I have got a man's coat and a mans [''sic''] bodice ... Auntie Gracie [Grace Mountain ''n√©e'' Tolkien] has been to see us I walk every day and only ride in my mailcart a little bit ... your loving Ronald.
